user_message:
<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 21.14 is: The Standard Library function memcmp shall not be used to compare null terminated strings.

</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of metal_linux_dev_dma_map:
```c
static int metal_linux_dev_dma_map(struct metal_bus *bus,
			     struct metal_device *device,
			     uint32_t dir,
			     struct metal_sg *sg_in,
			     int nents_in,
			     struct metal_sg *sg_out)
{
	struct linux_device *ldev = to_linux_device(device);
	struct linux_bus *lbus = to_linux_bus(bus);

	return ldev->ldrv->dev_dma_map(lbus, ldev, dir, sg_in,
				       nents_in, sg_out);
}
```
</target_code>
<additional code>Here are the definitions of symbols that are related to the target function metal_linux_dev_dma_map:
static struct linux_device *to_linux_device(struct metal_device *device)
{
	return metal_container_of(device, struct linux_device, device);
}
...
static struct linux_bus *to_linux_bus(struct metal_bus *bus)
{
	return metal_container_of(bus, struct linux_bus, bus);
}
</additional code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
explanation: No occurrences of memcmp are present in the provided code fragments. The functions shown only perform pointer conversions (metal_container_of) and delegate a call to ldev->ldrv->dev_dma_map; they do not perform any string operations or memory comparisons of null-terminated strings. There are no char* variables, no string.h usage, and no calls to strcmp/strncmp/memcmp in these fragments. If memcmp usage is of concern, it would have to be found in other code (for example inside dev_dma_map or elsewhere), but those implementations were not provided and therefore are out of scope for this review.
